standard_metadata.standard_description: Use a pair of perpendicular number lines, called axes, to define a coordinate system, with the intersection of the lines (the origin) arranged to coincide with the 0 on each line and a given point in the plane located by using an ordered pair of numbers, called its coordinates. Understand that the first number indicates how far to travel from the origin in the direction of one axis, and the second number indicates how far to travel in the direction of the second axis, with the convention that the names of the two axes and the coordinates correspond (e.g., x-axis and x-coordinate, y-axis and y-coordinate).

question.content: **What is the *y*-coordinate of the point plotted below?**

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from 1 to 6 from the origin in both the x and y-axis. A blue point is 2 units to the right of and 5 units up from the origin.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  $\begin{array}{} (\blueD{\text{distance right}},& \greenD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \blueD{x\text{-coordinate}}&\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$  We are asked to find the $\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}}$.
The $\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}}$ tells us the distance up from the origin.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from 1 to 4 from the origin in both the x and y-axis. The point the x and y-axis intersect is labeled origin.

hints.content: [[☃ image 1]]  The point is $5$ units above the origin.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from 1 to 6 from the origin in both the x and y-axis. A green arrow moves up from the second tick mark on the x-axis out to a point aligned with the number 5 on the y-axis.

hints.content: The $\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}}$ is $5$.
